div.p: When the Corbeau tribe were upon the eve of their departure Le Borgne sent word to Mr La Rocque to make ready and join them[.] And Mr La Rocque immediately set about arranging his matters for the Journey which the Gros ventres perceiving they crowded into our quarters and threatened Mr La Rocque with the effect of their displeasure if he persisted in his design[.] At this moment the great Chief entered with a battle axe in his hand[.] He stared around him and with an imperious air asked the Indians present why so many of them were assembled there[.] They answered that they were there only to take their last farewell of the White men whom they never expected to see again. "Why," said the Chief with a sneer,– ["]If the White people have a mind to die that is nothing to us[.] You have often enough warned them of the danger. Yet they will go on." The Indians in a moment sneaked out of the way – and we accompanied the Chief to the Corbeaux's Camp Mr La Rocque leading his horse by the bridle[.] When we entered the Camp of the Corbeauxs many of the tribe signified their disapprobation of Mr La Rocques intention and we could hear them exclaim "Where are You going White people. Return – go home to Your friends. We do not wish for Your Company. Many of our Young men are without sense; and We are afraid."

Their unfavorable appearances had no effect upon Mr La Rocque[s] resolution[.] But one of the men who was to have been of the party thought he found himself indisposed and applied for leave to remain with me[.] "I see plainly your sickness" 'said Mr La R' you are an old woman – You may therefore remain[.]" This unexpected discovery of the fellows weakness threw him into a violent passion and he was very abusive[.] However Mr La R. and took no notice of this conduct – for he could not punish so much insolence before so many strange Indians without injurying to some of our engagements[.]
